I also fell in love with it , the design was just amazing , the feel was great and the capability was very impressive when you consider at that time tablet's were barely around at the consumer level. Seeing the look on her face made it worth every single penny. Prior to getting the iPad she suffered a horrible infection and was hospitalized for 4 months fighting it , nearly losing her life in the process. She lost the capability to stand and only has use of her left hand now (with about 80 percent capability) and couple that with MS and you get someone who can't really use a mouse and keyboard setup easily.I wanted to state that before what I'm sure I will be accused of being a critical troll about the latest iPad version compared to a recent Android tablet I bought.Now onto the experience thus far with this new iPad , here is a list of what I like :1. LIGHT. Seriously , incredibly light. I can hold it in one hand very comfortably and its not meant to be held in such a way for the regular Joe ( I got big hamhocks for hands). I love it when technology trims up as it shows that its forward march is continuing without pause.2. FAST. Even over the iPad 4th generation this lean machine is even faster at multitasking which is good because it will help versus the recent Android tablet I bought which is a multitasking god.3. THIN BEZEL. If there is one complaint I have for the consumer electronics of the world in general its that we haven't done enough to remove overly large bezels from products. I hate them. I find they are a waste of real estate but I also realize that this is part of the technical limitation and the need for space for various reasons (board hardware , batteries and so on). The iPad Air's bezel is at least half of all previous iPad's. Very much appreciated Apple.Those are the biggest reasons to buy an iPad Air and they are really good ones in my mind. If you already own an iPad 4th gen though I don't think they are enough to justify the upgrade unless you really want the reduced weight (the iPad 4th gen is a pound and half while the iPad Air is only a pound flat).Now to the cons. And there are some that are very concerning and especially so if you tend to treat your products poorly (many people do..) :1. THIN PIECE OF GLASS. So while I realize that Gorilla Glass 3 is very impressive and amazing tough for its extremely thin profile .. I also feel its wildly out of place with a product like the iPad. People who buy iPad's and especially families tend to treat them pretty rough. I've seen children as young as 4 drop a 3rd gen iPad like a brick onto hardwood and it remained intact without a mark to bare. This new iPad Air has a very thin piece of GG3 that helps reduce the weight (and I would imagine the cost of manufacturing for Apple) but its recently been shown in several Youtube videos that when it comes to endurance its actually pretty fragile. Its very easy to crack it and especially so if it lands on its side. So while all the previous generation iPad's had a nice thick piece of glass to help protect the product this new one .. does not. It also sounds hollow when you tap it. And for some that drives them crazy. I don't mind this as I know its glass and not plastic like some "claim".2.COST. Since Apple did so much to slim down the cost of this new iPad and they used the EXACT same guts as the iPhone 5 (with a different layout and power profile) and yet they also trimmed down the battery size then how come this isn't any cheaper? The iPad mini is supposedly Apple's response to critics about the fact that its always the same price in each iteration. Apple , Android has fantastic alternatives now and the Google Play marketplace is becoming quite a fleshed out competitor , its time to start taking Android more seriously as a competitor and stop living inside your own eco bubble.3.SUB PAR HARDWARE VERSUS PRICE. Even with a new 64-bit chip (which isn't supported very well but that will change) the iPad is quite a puny product in terms of hardware specs. NOW BEFORE YOU FREAK OUT.. I know that Apple has optimized it heavily and that living in a very closed ecosystem (versus Android) gives it this advantage HOWEVER.. for what you are paying for you should be getting more. 1GB of RAM for instance? That's what I expect in a mid to low end smartphone these days. I can imagine those who complain (and have for a while now) about the random crashes because of running of memory would really love an extra 1GB of RAM for the iPad. I would also imagine it would do wonders for those who love to open programs by the truckload and not have to worry about random crashing errors due to running out of memory.Could you imagine a quad core A7 chip with 2 GB's of RAM? That beast would sing and you could do even more with an iPad that powerful. I would bet that when Apple moves towards 4k resolution that we will be getting those exact specs to run at that monster resolution but still I would have loved that right now.So my remarks about a recent Android tablet purchase.. I bought a Samsung Galaxy Note Pro 12.2 and I just have to say its a real beast and outshines Apple's best in many ways. The resolution is higher (2500x1600) and it comes with the S-Pen and S-Pen software plus an office suite of apps. Now the Note Pro 12.2 is made for business applications the price of it versus 64GB iPad is about a hundred more. But for that hundred more you get massive hardware support , with an OTG USB cable you can connect external hard drives to it , you can also add memory through SDXC cards (up to 128GB's) and Samsung's Touch Wiz is getting quite mature and really offers a very set of apps. Not to mention the screen size of 12.2 inches versus 9.7. However the iPad beats it in terms of weight , the Galaxy Note Pro 12.2 has a massive battery (but it lasts about 11 hours with heavy use) and the weight puts it into a class that speaks more towards laptop replacement that competitor to the iPad. However you can buy the non-pro versus for $100 less (you won't get the S-Pen) and still a get a monster solution.Android's tablet app market is getting better and better each week and there are plenty of apps that support landscape mode without issue. One thing I always thought Android did better was application scaling , something Apple could learn from frankly. The Galaxy Note 3 Pro in my mind is a Android finally getting its ducks in a row and Apple is going to have pick the pace to keep with Android's MASSIVE market share which is over double what Apple's is now.THAT BEING SAID.. I'm keeping the iPad Air. I love the Galaxy Note Pro 12.2 and its just a great tablet but I don't really have need of its business level features. But if I were going to recommend a tablet for a business minded individual I would recommend they go for it because it blows the iPad away for business use. The free office app it comes with is more fleshed out than MS Office for the iPad and the extra screen real estate is a big bonus for anyone attempting real work on it. But for a guy like me the iPad has an easier to consume profile and that's what I really love about it.If you intend to buy this product however (the iPad Air) I HIGHLY recommend you buy the Apple care warranty. You will be extremely glad you did with this powerful but more fragile new version of the iPad.

Reviews.Title: As a Laptop Replacement, No Real Downsides So Far
Reviews.Author: Marc Kennedy
Reviews.Content: I'm a grad student and when my laptop went on the fritz, this was my replacement.Pros - The Apple App Store is easier to navigate and more trustworthy in my opinion than the Android app store.- like my iPhone, the interface is clean and much less cluttered than my Samsung tablet- the onscreen keyboard is very useable- there are a lot of available accessories, as should be expected- this seemed like less of a toy to me than a Kindle Fire- free iWork apps- so lightweight- great battery life- the screen is beautiful- I can download all my docs from DropboxCons- the external button to put it to sleep is small- it may just be the screen protector I purchased (Tech Armor clear), but the distance between the home button and the edge of the bezel is small and the screen protector will not seal there- no fingerprint scanner like the iPhone 5s- there is currently not a flawless PDF app for iPad, so using Adobe reader on my laptop was a better experience

Reviews.Title: Ipad Air
Reviews.Author: Sallyann Wagoner
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this!!  I use it to replace my computer when I am just doing web searches and reading magazines.  I love all the apps it has available and I have even gotten my husband to use it too.  This replaces my original Ipad which I received for Valentine's day the first year the Ipad came out.  It still works great, but is slow and has no camera.  Buy this now!!!Sallyann

Reviews.Title: Fantastic iPad air
Reviews.Author: Tiffney Brink
Reviews.Content: It was brand new right out of the factory package. It has an amazing battery life and a beautiful display.

Reviews.Title: Much better than my iPad 1.
Reviews.Author: Herb Lippe "Indi"
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my iPad Generation 1.  Much faster, clearer, LIGHTER, and more powerful.I think I made one mistake that has caused a minor problem with Safari. Instead of setting everything up from scratch, I downloaded everything from my the Cloud Storage for my iPhone 5S. The problem is I can get TABS in Safari.  I bypassed this by using the Mercury Browser and, as soon as the Christmas panic dies down, I'll bring it in to an Apple store and see what I did wrong.Definitely worth the upgrade.

Reviews.Title: Lives up to the hype
Reviews.Author: S. Harrison "LovePinkCJ"
Reviews.Content: I've been true to Apple for many years but recently took the plunge and went to Samsung for my smartphone.  I almost got the Samsung tablet but just couldn't bring myself to it.  If you love Apple...  you'll love the newer, leaner, and cleaner design and OS. If you're technologically advanced...  I'm sure you'll find the flaws but you'll still enjoy the iPad Air.

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Helena R McMaster
Reviews.Content: This is my first iPad.  So I can't compare to any of the others.  It looks great feels great, and most importantly it works great and once you get the easy setup process done it operates great and very easy to use.  I did feel the need to purchase a case because it is very thin and light weight.  I purchased the survivor case.  Great for this case, makes the weight heavier but protects if dropped.

Reviews.Title: iPad air crashes ! ! !
Reviews.Author: Hank
Reviews.Content: It's a nice tablet. Fairly fast. I got the AT&T; model and internet connections are fast. However, the darn thing crashes frequently !Very aggravating.

Reviews.Title: Simply the best
Reviews.Author: Jenny Delamotte
Reviews.Content: Do you remember being in grade school and having the kid you were in love with pick on you or make fun of you on the playground?  Remember what your mom and dad explained to you was the reason for that public humiliation?  Because they liked you too!  The same principle applies to all the competitors that say bad things about the iPad.  It's because secretly, they want to BE the iiPad.You can buy a competitor's product, but any way you slice it, it won't even begin to measure up. Just remember, every time they say something negative, they are really saying how much they love the iPad.  Nothing else compares to the bright screen on the iPad Air, or the way that it feel resting ever so lightly in your hands.  It just feels right.And that is what Apple has done so right.  It never wavered or varied based on the negative opinions of other companies.  It never even responded to them.  On the playground Apple walks away without a scratch, without trying, and without lifting a finger to respond to any other tablet's challenge.  It doesn't have to.  And everybody loves it.  See, mom really does know best.

Reviews.Title: Great product but must return it due to multiple issues
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Had to give this three stars because even though I loved the product I had problems with it. First off, the iPad arrived slightly scratched from shipping. I contacted amazon and decided to settle on getting a partial refund as I didn't want to go through the hassle (international customer) and also the item was working well and the scratch marks were on the back which I decided would be covered by a case anyway. However, after a couple weeks of (light) use it developed a blue line across the screen. I am sending it back. I wont buy another iPad from amazon though because what I have come to realize is that the warranty starts from the date the seller purchased the product meaning that I only have a few months left on this warranty. I'm just glad I figured this out sooner rather than later. Excellent product overall and great customer service from amazon in sorting out the issue.-Update- I have since received my refund and purchased a new iPad from Apple. What I realized immediately was how differently this one was packaged. The one I ordered on amazon did not come sealed and did not have plastic on either the screen or the back. Plus I had mentioned before that there were scruff marks on it. I strongly suspect that the original iPad I purchased here was not new as advertised. Buyers beware.

Reviews.Title: Great piece of machinery, amazing app store, sucky memory.
Reviews.Author: Pam A.
Reviews.Content: You may be thinking to yourself right now that 16 GB is right for you. And if you are using this for the sole purpose of creating, sharing, and presenting documents, maintaining your schedule, and taking a few photos. That's great. However, I  tend to watch a few movies, but considering that I only actually have 12 GB of memory after software, large apps like pages and keynote, books, and few photos (less than 100) are taken into account, I can only put one on at a time, which gets a little old after awhile. The fact that apply doesn't allow expanded memory like memory cards still frustrates me to this day because you never know what you may want to put on your tablet in the future, and this leaves you no room to breathe. I hate the restrictions and the only real reason why I decided to get the IPad over the Samsung Note series is because the app store is incredible and much more versatile. I will certainly NEVER get another IPhone after having a Samsung galaxy unless Apple introduces the expanded memory.Anyway, moral of the story: Ipad Air is sleek, light, fast, functions well, has a great display and app store (that just being Apple in general). And if you REALLY have your heart set on this, I would genuinely think twice about the memory you choose. I don't regret buying this, it has served me in more ways than one. I just wish I had bounced for the 32 GB.

I also love how I can load the Amazon Video app and watch Prime on my iPad or Airplay to my Apple TV.  I love that I can sync my iPad to my computer for backups and to organize music and videos.  Now for the caveat.  Apple needs to increase the basic memory for these.  I could not afford to pay another $100 for the 32 gb Air.  16 gb does not last very long!  I want more memory!!  The available memory is more like 11-12 gb because the OS takes up the rest of the space.  Apple may never put a memory card slot in the iPads - they should, they could make it proprietary and sell them for a good markup, (not $100!) then they would make more money on volume sales! Reviews.Title: Apple is the Best!!!!
Reviews.Author: BioHazard
Reviews.Content: I love the new IPad Air. I got it the day it came out in stores. It starts with the ultra-sharp exterior. If you loved last year's iPad Mini, you'll feel right at home with the Air. Apple essentially built a larger version of the Mini with the Air, by slimming the beveling of previous iPads to achieve a sleeker framework.The lack of heft makes the Air just a little more comfortable: An LTE-equipped Air weighs all of 1.05 pounds. Wrapped in a comfy and protective Apple Smart Case, the Air weighs 1.368 pounds, still lighter than a third-generation iPad by itself. Despite the lack of size, the Air is no less tough. It's sturdy and not at all easy to bend.The Air feels that much more like an electronic magazine. The Retina display, once the standard for all screens but also facing more competition this year, helps that; reading text and viewing web pages on that crystal-clear, pixel-dense screen is the same joy it was when Apple first built Retina screens into its tablets early last year.If this is all Apple did, it would likely still be enough to keep it on top. But the iPad Air does far more, starting with the new processor powering the entire experience, the A7. The same dual-core, 64-bit A7 chip that debuted in the iPhone 5S is in the iPad Air; and initially, this seems like a disappointment. In theory, you expect something more in Apple's flagship tablet, something a bit more powerful, with perhaps more graphical horsepower.In practice, you won't notice a thing. Web browsing and apps still handle as snappily as ever, even if you have a gaggle of things running in the background. Top-tier games such as Infinity Blade 3 continue to deliver. A pleasant surprise is also how quickly some of the beefier games, such as Anomaly 2, loaded, compared to previous iPads. You'll move into and out of levels just a little bit more swiftly, and that helps make the entire gaming experience more friendly and natural. It's hard to know what this really means for Apple gaming, but don't rule out the possibility of more console titles being ported to the iPad.Apple realizes the limitations of the 64 GB storage too, offering a new 128-gig model. You'll pay a more-than-average-laptop premium here ($799 for the WiFi-only model and $929 for an LTE version), but the improved storage is intriguing, especially for those planning for a game-heavy future. I can now easily and comfortably load all the music and movies onto the iPad Air that I want and still have plenty of room left over for games such as XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Civilization: Revolutions.Battery life is steady, even if it's not mind-blowing. Apple claims the iPad Air can get you 10 hours on a charge, and that's definitely true. Even when using Apple's navigation for a long trip to Washington, I easily got through a day without needing to charge; and more casual usage, such as Web browsing and email checks, is no problem.The Air's lone shortcoming is that it lacks the fingerprint identification technology that debuted on the iPhone 5S. But I'd be hard-pressed to claim that this was some glaring omission; every other tablet you're going to use this year lacks such tech, and I've never seen that tech as an absolute must-have.The resulting tablet is as pleasant to use as they come, and it's backed by some consistently solid software. Android has made a tremendous run over the past few years, and a plethora of both Android and Windows Mobile devices are truly intriguing this holiday season. But if there's one consistent shortcoming on those devices, it's the up-and-down support of operating systems.It's hard to know whether this Android tab or that will support Google's latest OS, but that's almost never a problem with iPads. iOS releases are generally consistent and stable, the lone knock on Apple being its lack of Android-like customization.And while the Apps Store and iTunes are also battling competition from Microsoft's stores and Google's Marketplace, Apple's setup continues to set the bar, managing to be intuitive and easy to use and enjoying more and more high-profile digital releases.

Reviews.Title: Seems to me to be the best tablet out there (but you've got to be willing to pay a premium for it)
Reviews.Author: Kenneth Cooper
Reviews.Content: Some of these reviews from people who have supposedly purchased or used this device are a bit bogus (comments that don't match with the reality that actual device owners are experiencing).  Let's hope that those who are coming here for 'guidance' are also reading professional reviews from trusted media sources .. and .. talking to actual users of the product.My review: After trying several of the latest high resolution tablets on the market I returned all but one, the iPad Air. I can't find a thing about it to complain about (except the price). It's just outstanding in every way (display, size, weight, available apps, and operating system). It also addressed certain niggling complaints I had with my earlier iPads. With regard to other devices I tried, the latest Kindle Fires were excellent (great displays - and the price was right) but not sufficiently versatile to meet all my needs. The LG 8.3 was another excellent Android tablet but it didn't seem like a truly finished product (couldn't, for instance, lock it in landscape mode - very frustrating when trying to use it while lying in bed). It also seemed a bit pricy for what it was at nearly the price of an iPad Mini Retina (a tablet I was seriously considering for its portability). For what it's worth, the only tablets I tried, or even wanted to try, were those with very high pixel density displays. Later I also ruled out the true 7 inch devices with their 22 square inch displays (the iPad Mini's is 30 square inches, the LG 8.3's is 31, while the iPad Air's is 45). In other words, most of what else was out there had screens that were either too small or displays that were not sufficiently retina like.

Reviews.Content: I am not an Apple loyalist, I much preferred Windows (before Windows 8 came out anyway), and droid over the i-phone.  Even now, I get annoyed at some Apple-isms, the way Apple does some things, and try to stay away from it for the most part.  But I do believe it's typically more stable than it's technological counterparts, and easier to use for newbies.  Which is why we bought an IPAD 2 for our 8 yr old a couple years ago.  He took to it right away, it's intuitive enough.  There have been some slight issues, but it's still going strong.  Now 10, we just bought him this IPAD AIR... his 2 yr old brother gets the "old" IPAD 2.  And yes, the IPAD is intuitive enough for even a 2 yr old!  The screen on the AIR is so much better, clearer, sharper, and not just because it's "new".  Its resolution is just that much better.  Bought a cheap full body case until I could find a better one... trying to decide between the Otterbox (love the protection, not so much the hard cover design and that it doubles as a stand)... the Griffin Survivor (flimsy stand, landscape mode only)... or the Pelican Vault (no integrated screen protector, but I can put a protector on, and it is rated against water splash)... Lifeproof too expensive for what it offers... The 16G in the IPAD 2 was ultimately not enough after a year or so of use... Even with no "movies" or "music", games are much larger now, a few big games, and there is little left in a 16G device.  Without removing games, we didn't have enough memory left to upgrade the OS... so we opted for 64G this time... Though not an Apple fan, my 2 sons love them, I seldom have to "fix" anything with them, and so I rate it 5-stars!

They  don't deserved to be considered in the same breath.  Their engineering is all over the spectrum, but never reach the heights of Apple's flawless execution.  I attribute android's failure to it's architecture around Java and old school mentality of making a product that works, sells, but never excels.  There's literally no better alternative  than an apple device, and I am not a Steve Jobs fan.

Reviews.Author: Pamela Paulhamus
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love my iPad Air!  I spent months doing product comparisons.  I spoke to many tech geeks at various stores in addition to reading hundreds of on-line reviews.  The one thing I wanted to know was if I could load photos from my camera's SD card into the iPad.  Everyone said no!  Even the people in the stores SELLING them!  They were wrong!  Apple has two items that allow for this.  I purchased the Lightning to SD Card Reader ($27) and it works beautifully.  I took the iPad with me on two recent trips.  It was great being able to transfer my photos daily into the iPad to view them as opposed to trying to look at them on my camera!  With the 128GB of storage, I can keep quite a few photos stored on the iPad.  There are many apps available for photo editing and sharing.  I love everything about the iPad!  It was also nice having it on the long flights....between looking at my photos and playing all the games I have loaded into it, the time just flew by!  Of course, there are many other reasons to love the iPad, but for me, being able to view and edit photos while away from home is priceless.  I wouldn't want to ever fly with my laptop because of the weight.  But the iPad Air...it's a real gem!  Weight-wise...it weighs less than most books I might have taken with me to read!  I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Air or mini, cellular or wifi? The hardest choice.
Reviews.Author: Mumbly Joe "MumblyJoe"
Reviews.Content: A lot of people have already talked about the merits of this device and the pros and cons. For me the decision wasn't so much which to buy but rather which one I wanted. Originally I got the mini to replace my kindle touch because of the price and the pocketable size. Ultimately I ended up with the air. Here's why:Grip: despite the very comfortable dimensions for 1 handed holding of the mini the extra thin bezel proved problematic. The palm rejection tech is supposed to be quite good but I found it unreliable and for those times I wanted to gets.  Eventually I always wanted to get a hold of it with  the bezel between my thumb and forefinger but either ended up with a thumb right in the middle of whatever I was watching or a hand cramp.Real estate: getting smaller means text is smaller especially on we pages In portrait mode. You can set the text size up for dynamic type but it doesn't work everywhere and when if does work and you change to landscape, then the text is far too big for the screen. Furthermore, in games where part of the screen is used for the controls I ended up wishing for a larger screen.Keyboard: the keyboard ended up being the main reason I went for the Air. While it is surprisingly good on the mini (really it blew me away how good the keyboard was in the mini) typing at that size for any extended period is taxing and it just can't compete with the Air if you plan on writing any amount. Furthermore, using the GarageBand keyboards are fairly awkward on the smaller screen. Unlike the accessory keyboards for the full size iPads, I found the external keyboards for the mini were actually much much worse than the onscreen keyboard.Pocketability: the mini fit quite nicely into a jacket pocket, in the climate where I live jackets are only really feasible about 3 or 4 months out of the year. Other than that it needs bag of some sort, which is really the same situation I'd be in with an Air.Weight: this made the choice the hardest. Holding the iPad mini feels like hardly anything at all. The iPad air feels considerably heavier. That affects everything you do with the tablet and the entire interaction with it. Fortunately it's mostly a matter of perspective. Put down the mini for a day and all of a sudden the air seems  quite light.For me the decision was made for the larger version but what about options?Cellular of no cellular? The free 3G on my kindle touch has gotten me out of a scrape more than once and having access to a no-strings-attached internet connection is guaranteed to come in handy at least once during the lifetime of your tablet. $130 is a lot to spend though, especially if you have a smart phone and free tethering on your plan. Originally I went for the wifi version for precisely this reason. However, the ability to tether is dependent on the carrier you happen to be using. Should you switch phones, carriers or plans or simply lose the phone while traveling tethering May no longer be a option and it's never going to be as convenient as simply opening the settings on your iPad and activating a plan. In addition you also gain the ability to use gps with a cellular modem and gain the benefits of enhanced find my iPhone accuracy in the event that it's stolen and the thieves know enough to keep it off wifi. Finally though, the possibility of a free 200 mb per month with t-mobile and the ability to switch carriers at will ended up pushing me to get the cellular version.So, after having initially been interested by the mini, a lot  of research, even more indecision and having bought, lived with and sold multiple versions of this thing I can safely say that the iPad Air with cellular is the  version I'd pick. If you don't plan on typing a lot with it though or watching movies, go for the mini.

Thought I’d give the iPad a try.Pros:- It’s super light in weight which makes it ideal for carrying.- It’s fast. Apps run very nicely.- Great camera and photo tools.- Beautiful screen! I needed an SD card reader, an HDMI connector for streaming video to TVs in hotels, and a Micro SD connector  for my smart phone and other devices. The HDMI connector itself was $50.00. This thing probably cost $0.50 to make, but I WAS warned  about Apple’s marketing tactics…- The manual leaves a bit to be desired. I’ve learned more from friends then I have from their manual. Reviews.Title: Poor Product
Reviews.Author: Alan Dale Daniel
Reviews.Content: My thoughts on the latest ipad Air from Apple.  First, try to buy the product through Amazon.  If you get lucky you will avoid 38+ dollars in taxes.  In my state I get charged that anyway.  I bought mine a few weeks ago and I now regret my decision.The ipad Air, full size not the mini, is expensive for what you get.  The much talked about retina display really isn’t much better than Apple’s or Samsung’s normal display.  I take a lot of photos and even at full zoom I can’t make out much difference.  The Apple ipad Air does NOT come with an SD card slot, and if you want to upgrade from 16gb to 32gb you will be looking at over $100 additional dollars.  Many of Apple’s competitors have the SD slot and cost less.Apple sells an SD card “reader.”  You can download from the card to the ipad but NOT the other way.  And the ipad SD card reader will run you $30 plus dollars.  You must buy other $30+ dollar accessories if you want to use a USB memory stick for example.  I purchased a non- Apple SD card triple reader (USB and SD for example) for about $9 dollars.  The machine complains at me but it still works (but, once again, it only loads to the machine not from the ipad as a normal SD slot does).An SD card reader would have been easy to install as part of the iPad, and this gives their competitors an edge, especially when one is taking photographs and trying to download them immediately to examine on something other than a 2 inch screen.  As I shoot RAW (large files) photos with my Canon this inability to use an SD card is a real pain.Downloading music from Amazon to iTunes isn’t any picnic either.  My wife has an android device from Dell running Jellybean and she downloads everything with zero problems.  Plus, she has an SD card slot which really helps.  Her screen is as sharp as mine.Finally, the OS systems.  Jellybean has about a million apps written for it while I have about 200 - or that is how it seems to me.  Her system is faster than mine AND her system is intuitive and mine is not.  I’ve had to read over the Apple manual for ipad three times trying to get things done.  Maybe my largest gripe is I bought the Apple thinking several Apple machines could sync up and trade information easily including photographs and music and documents.  Wrong.  I’ve tried numerous syncing ideas and none of them work.  I started using Pages (an Apple word processing program) instead to Word to get it to transfer.  Finally, I saved it to the cloud and managed to get the document to the other machine.  Photographs that are in the photo stream do transfer; however, getting the photograph into the stream when it was not automatically placed there by the ipad doesn’t work.  And finding photos to look at in the ipad, when the ipad did not take the photo and the photo is on another machine (with the photo stream on and home sharing on) the photo still does not come up.  Very frustrating.After using the ipad and watching and using Jellybean and Android in action I think the Android devices are a much better deal.  Get one with an SD card slot.  I am certain Apple has designed their machine so the user cannot get extra storage on the machine (as an SD slot would allow) and must buy a more expensive machine if they handle large files.  If you like buying music at Amazon good luck getting it to iTunes onto your machine if it is an Apple (Yes, I have Amazon cloud player).  My wife got her music downloaded in about a minute.  It took me an hour to get one of Mozart’s songs I had purchased downloaded to my computer.In retrospect, since the programs do NOT sync up as advertised, the machine has little storage unless you pay an enormous additional price, the retina display is not revolutionary, and the number of programs are minimal compared to Android I wish I had purchased an Android.  Samsung seems to be on the cutting edge there, although my wife’s Dell is performing just fine.

The thing is I can not justify spending hundreds of $$$ on a product that should have been designed better.  Hopefully in 2014 the next iPad Air model will put the S T E R E O speakers on the FRONT of the device.UPDATE 12/4/2013: I just came back from The Apple Store to make it "official" that I have used an iPad Air.  Yes the iPad Air is thinner than previous iPad models and it may be faster.  Honestly I didn't see much of a difference in speed between the iPad Air and the iPad 4 while surfing the web.  That said I still see no reason to get an iPad Air if you already own an iPad 4.

Reviews.Title: I Really, Really Wanted To Like The iPad Air
Reviews.Author: MARCIA
Reviews.Content: I really, really wanted to like the iPad Air, but It just wasn't for me. I was looking for a replacement for my 2008 white Macbook, which I loved. The iPad Air is NOT, repeat not a laptop replacement. I don't have heavy computing requirements, but the brand new iPad couldn't do a number of BASIC things my 5 and a half year old Macbook does with ease.The most important is multitasking. The iPad can only do one thing at a time. Only one window or app can be open at a time. Seriously? iPad doesn't do flash player, so any number of things (like watching certain youtube videos,etc) can't be done.I found the touch screen to be inconsistent. I was constantly having to enlarge links to be able to click them properly. I was also disappointed with the small amount of included apps.Now the good: If you want a portable device to check email, browse the web, take pictures,etc and you tend to do one thing at a time, the iPad may work for you. The retina display and the fit and finish of the iPad are excellent. It is light, thin, fast, and beautiful. Siri is included and works well.I love Apple products, but I found the iPad to be underpowered and lacking versatility. If you're looking for a laptop replacement, I couldn't recommend it. I ended up returning it and got a Macbook Pro instead.
